prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum + [CII] measurements: 17806, 9574, 5168, 9134
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Continuum and [CII] tuning in band 7 to include 4 objects. All these objects have redshifts allowing to detect [CII] with the same single tuning.
DUPLICATION: No duplication has been found with the published cycle 2 list and the ALMA archive. Although some of our targets are in the fields of existing ALMA pointings, the corresponding data has neither been taken in band 7, nor with a sufficient sensitivity.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We select the low spectral resolution mode (TDM) used in dual polarization. It provides the largest effective bandwidth of 1875 MHz per baseband and the lowest spectral resolution of 31.25 MHz in the ALMA band 7. This is the most efficient mode for the continuum, and also for the [CII] emission line given its expected FWHM of ~200 km/s. At the TDM spectral resolution of ~27 km/s at the sky frequency set in band 7, we will still have 7 spectral resolution elements per [CII] line width.
We define 4 spectral TDM windows, two inside each sidebands (LSB and USB). The spectral windows are such that one of them includes the redshifted [CII] line for 4 of the objects. The remaining basebands are used for the continuum only.

The proposed ALMA observations target Lyman-break galaxies at z~4.2-4.8.
All our sources are compact in the HST images. They can thus be observed with a single pointing in the most compact configuration C36-1 of the 12-m array. At the observed frequency in band 7, this corresponds to 1".
For point sources, the largest angular scale has no importance, therefore we have set this parameter to 0.0.

With band 7 centered at 158 micron we will probe the thermal dust emission close to its peak. It can therefore be translated to a total IR luminosity (8-1000 micron) with a typical accuracy of ~0.3 dex, as derived from various spectral templates (modified black-bodies or semi-empirical templates). We aim for an rms of 50 microJy in the continuum, which - for our sources at z=4.2-4.8 - translates to an 1-sigma limit of ~2.e10 Lsun in IR luminosity (i.e. log(L_IR/Lsun)~10.3).
The requested depth will thus allow the detection of sources with log(L_IR/Lsun)>=10.8 at >=3 sigma. This is close to the mininum luminosity expected from SED fits, as shown in Fig. 4 (left). However, these predictions are strongly model-dependent (depending on SF history, age, the attenuation law etc.), and recent observations at z>5 by Capak et al. have shown unexpectedly faint dust continuum emission. In any case our targetted sensitivity will allow us to reach limits on the UV attenuation of A_UV~0.2 (at 3 sigma) for the UV brightest objects and A_UV~1 for the UV faintest (cf. Fig 4, left). These limits are sufficient to reach all our goals.
For the [CII]158 micron line, to which we are tuning, we will reach limits L(CII)~(1.5-2)*e7 Lsun (at 1 sigma), if we assume the same line widths (FWHM~60-120 km/s) as observed in the z~5-5.7 SF galaxies by Capak et al. From the SFR-L(CII) relation of de Looze et al. (2011, 2014) this corresponds to a limit of SFR~1.5 Msun/yr. We therefore expect to detect significantly all our targets, except if [CII] emission is (strongly) decreased e.g. in sources well above the main sequence (cf. Diaz-Santos et al. 2013).

We have chosen non standard continuum frequencies in order to cover the frequency of the redshifted [CII] emission lines of our objects. We have optimized the tuning in the way to have 4 spectral TDM windows, two inside each sidebands (LSB and USB). The spectral windows are such that one of them includes the redshifted [CII] line for 4 of the objects. The remaining basebands are used for the continuum only.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum + [CII] measurements: 12043, 10536, 12130, 24679, 13375, 3753, 8212, 24625, 17102
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Continuum and [CII] tuning in band 7 to include 9 objects. 8 of these objects have redshifts allowing to detect [CII] with the same single tuning.
DUPLICATION: No duplication has been found with the published cycle 2 list and the ALMA archive. Although some of our targets are in the fields of existing ALMA pointings, the corresponding data has neither been taken in band 7, nor with a sufficient sensitivity.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We select the low spectral resolution mode (TDM) used in dual polarization. It provides the largest effective bandwidth of 1875 MHz per baseband and the lowest spectral resolution of 31.25 MHz in the ALMA band 7. This is the most efficient mode for the continuum, and also for the [CII] emission line given its expected FWHM of ~200 km/s. At the TDM spectral resolution of ~27 km/s at the sky frequency set in band 7, we will still have 7 spectral resolution elements per [CII] line width.
We define 4 spectral TDM windows, two inside each sidebands (LSB and USB). The spectral windows are such that one of them includes the redshifted [CII] line for 8 of the objects. The remaining basebands are used for the continuum only.

The proposed ALMA observations target Lyman-break galaxies at z~4.2-4.8.
All our sources are compact in the HST images. They can thus be observed with a single pointing in the most compact configuration C36-1 of the 12-m array. At the observed frequency in band 7, this corresponds to 1".
For point sources, the largest angular scale has no importance, therefore we have set this parameter to 0.0.

With band 7 centered at 158 micron we will probe the thermal dust emission close to its peak. It can therefore be translated to a total IR luminosity (8-1000 micron) with a typical accuracy of ~0.3 dex, as derived from various spectral templates (modified black-bodies or semi-empirical templates). We aim for an rms of 50 microJy in the continuum, which - for our sources at z=4.2-4.8 - translates to an 1-sigma limit of ~2.e10 Lsun in IR luminosity (i.e. log(L_IR/Lsun)~10.3).
The requested depth will thus allow the detection of sources with log(L_IR/Lsun)>=10.8 at >=3 sigma. This is close to the mininum luminosity expected from SED fits, as shown in Fig. 4 (left). However, these predictions are strongly model-dependent (depending on SF history, age, the attenuation law etc.), and recent observations at z>5 by Capak et al. have shown unexpectedly faint dust continuum emission. In any case our targetted sensitivity will allow us to reach limits on the UV attenuation of A_UV~0.2 (at 3 sigma) for the UV brightest objects and A_UV~1 for the UV faintest (cf. Fig 4, left). These limits are sufficient to reach all our goals.
For the [CII]158 micron line, to which we are tuning, we will reach limits L(CII)~(1.5-2)*e7 Lsun (at 1 sigma), if we assume the same line widths (FWHM~60-120 km/s) as observed in the z~5-5.7 SF galaxies by Capak et al. From the SFR-L(CII) relation of de Looze et al. (2011, 2014) this corresponds to a limit of SFR~1.5 Msun/yr. We therefore expect to detect significantly all our targets, except if [CII] emission is (strongly) decreased e.g. in sources well above the main sequence (cf. Diaz-Santos et al. 2013).

We have chosen non standard continuum frequencies in order to cover the frequency of the redshifted [CII] emission lines of our objects. We have optimized the tuning in the way to have 4 spectral TDM windows, two inside each sidebands (LSB and USB). The spectral windows are such that one of them includes the redshifted [CII] line for 8 of the objects. The remaining basebands are used for the continuum only.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose ALMA Band 7 observations of a sample of 13 spectroscopically confirmed LBGs at z=4.2-4.8, a unique redshift window where IRAC/Spitzer photometry probes the Halpha emission line, and thereby provides a measure of the instantaneous specific star formation rate (sSFR) of these galaxies. Our SED modeling of the UV/optical/NIR broadband emission of these galaxies show possibly a large scatter in sSFR, indicative of "stochasticity" of star formation which could question the main sequence paradigm. However, important degeneracies and uncertainties remain.
The ALMA observations will measure for the first time the IR luminosity and thus directly the UV attenuation of these galaxies, providing badly needed new empirical constraints and breaking degeneracies in SED fits.
At the same time we will observe the [CII] 158 micron line, which will provide an independent constraint on the SFR and on the distance from the main sequence.
The proposed observations will test the main sequence paradigm at z~4-5 and provide important fundamental measurements for LBGs at this redshift. Our results should have important implications for our understanding of galaxy formation
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
